docs.lead_paragraph: Middlemen and marketing costs have long been viewed with suspicion by critics of commerce. But these practices are usually signs of market sophistication, not waste.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Army Brigade, Long a Symbol of Readiness, Is Stretched Thin'' (front page, March 20):
docs.abstract: Letter from Prof David Fassler supports pending legislation that would expand access to coverage for treatment of mental illness (March 19 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      Re ''Army Brigade, Long a Symbol of Readiness, Is Stretched Thin'' (front page, March 20):

docs.lead_paragraph: Testifying at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pleaded for at least $150 million in annual federal aid to monitor and treat thousands of people who became ill after being exposed to dust and debris at ground zero. The mayor also called for the creation of a special fund to compensate those who became sick, urging that the city and its contractors be protected from potentially ruinous liability as a result of lawsuits brought by rescue and recovery workers who have argued that they were not adequately protected from the environmental hazards left by the World Trade Center's collapse.

headline.main: Bloomberg Seeks U.S. Aid for Treatment of 9/11 Illnesses

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg testifies at Senate hearing on need for at least $150 million in annual federal aid to monitor and treat thousands of people who became ill after being exposed to dust and debris of World Trade Center on Sept 11, 2001; also calls for creation of special fund to compensate those who became sick, noting that more than 8,000 workers have joined lawsuits accusing city and some 150 contractors of neglecting to protect them at ground zero; Senators from both parties express sympathy for Bloomberg's arguments; Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton says compensation fund is important proposal, but stops short of endorsing it; photo (M)
